Subject: Combined Science
Specification: 1SC0 (Pearson Edexcel Level 1/Level 2 GCSE (9-1) in Combined Science) Issue 6 (March 2024)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Eukaryotic and prokaryotic cell sub-cellular structures and function
Sub_topics.description: Explain how sub-cellular structures are related to their functions in: animal cells (nucleus, cell membrane, mitochondria, ribosomes); plant cells (nucleus, cell membrane, cell wall, chloroplasts, mitochondria, vacuole, ribosomes); bacteria/prokaryotic cells (chromosomal DNA, plasmid DNA, cell membrane, ribosomes, flagella). Link structure to role (e.g. control, transport barrier, energy release, protein synthesis, photosynthesis, support, storage, movement, genetic information).

Describe how specialised cells are adapted to their functions, including: sperm cells (acrosome, haploid nucleus, many mitochondria, tail/flagellum); egg cells (nutrients in cytoplasm, haploid nucleus, changes in cell membrane after fertilisation to prevent polyspermy); ciliated epithelial cells (cilia movement and role, e.g. moving mucus/particles).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Microscope technology and understanding of organelles
Sub_topics.description: Explain how changes in microscope technology, including electron microscopy, have enabled clearer and more detailed observation of cell structures/organelles compared with the past, and how this increased understanding of the roles of sub-cellular structures.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Number, size and scale (cells) and estimation
Sub_topics.description: Demonstrate understanding of number, size and scale for biological structures, including using estimations, and explain when estimations are appropriate in biology (e.g. very small dimensions, limited measurement precision).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Units and standard form in cell measurements
Sub_topics.description: Demonstrate understanding of quantitative units and prefixes relevant to cells and sub-cellular structures: milli (10⁻³), micro (10⁻⁶), nano (10⁻⁹), pico (10⁻¹²); include calculations using numbers in standard form for very large/small values and converting between these units.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical: Microscopy, magnification and biological drawings
Sub_topics.description: Core Practical: Investigate biological specimens using microscopes. Skills include setting up and using a light microscope, preparing slides (as required by centre method), focusing and observing specimens, identifying visible structures, producing labelled scientific drawings from observations (appropriate title/labels, clear lines, scale where appropriate), and performing magnification calculations (magnification = image size ÷ actual size) with correct units and conversions.

Explain the mechanism of enzyme action including the active site model and enzyme specificity (shape/chemical complementarity between active site and substrate; enzyme-substrate complex; products released; enzymes unchanged and reusable).

Explain how enzymes can be denatured due to changes in the shape of the active site (e.g. caused by high temperature or extreme pH), leading to reduced/ceased activity because substrates no longer bind effectively.

Explain the effects of temperature, substrate concentration and pH on enzyme activity, including ideas of increased collision frequency at higher temperature up to an optimum, reduced activity beyond optimum due to denaturation, and effects of substrate concentration on rate until active sites become saturated. Include pH effects on active site/tertiary structure and optimum pH for particular enzymes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical: Effect of pH on enzyme activity
Sub_topics.description: Core Practical: Investigate the effect of pH on enzyme activity using amylase acting on starch at different pH values. Monitor reaction using iodine to test for starch with a continuous sampling method; maintain temperature using a water bath heated with a Bunsen burner and beaker; measure time/endpoint consistently; control variables (temperature, volumes/concentrations, mixing). Interpret results as rate changes with pH.

Demonstrate understanding of rate calculations for enzyme activity, using appropriate quantitative measures (e.g. rate = change in product or substrate ÷ time; comparing times to complete reactions; interpreting rate from graphs where relevant).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Enzymes as biological catalysts (synthesis and breakdown)
Sub_topics.description: Explain the importance of enzymes as biological catalysts in: synthesis of carbohydrates, proteins and lipids; and breakdown (digestion/metabolism) of carbohydrates into sugars, proteins into amino acids, and lipids into fatty acids and glycerol. Link to specificity and speed of reactions in cells/organisms.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Transport in and out of cells
Sub_topics.description: Explain transport into and out of cells by diffusion (net movement down concentration gradient), osmosis (diffusion of water through a partially permeable membrane from high water potential/dilute solution to low water potential/concentrated solution), and active transport (movement against concentration gradient requiring energy/ATP and carrier proteins). Apply to examples such as nutrient uptake and ion transport.

Core Practical: Investigate osmosis in potatoes by measuring mass change. Method: measure initial mass of potato pieces, immerse in sucrose solutions of known concentration for a set time, remove/blot dry, measure final mass, and calculate percentage change. Use results to infer direction of water movement and estimate sucrose concentration inside potato tissue; discuss variable control and repeatability.
Calculate percentage gain and loss of mass in osmosis experiments using % change = (final mass − initial mass) ÷ initial mass × 100. Interpret positive/negative values in terms of net water movement.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mitosis stages in the cell cycle
Sub_topics.description: Describe mitosis as part of the cell cycle, including the stages: interphase, prophase, metaphase, anaphase, telophase, and cytokinesis. Include key events per stage at GCSE level (DNA replication in interphase; chromosome condensation; alignment; separation of chromatids; nucleus re-formation; cytoplasm division).
Describe the importance of mitosis in growth, repair of tissues, and asexual reproduction, linking to production of genetically identical cells.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Outcome of mitosis: identical diploid daughter cells
Sub_topics.description: Describe cell division by mitosis as producing two daughter cells with identical sets of chromosomes in the nucleus to the parent cell, resulting in two genetically identical diploid body cells.
Describe cancer as the result of changes in cells that lead to uncontrolled cell division; relate to disruption of the cell cycle and formation of tumours.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Growth in organisms: division, elongation, differentiation
Sub_topics.description: Describe growth in organisms: (a) animals—cell division and differentiation; (b) plants—cell division, elongation and differentiation. Link to increased cell number and cell specialisation.
Explain the importance of cell differentiation in the development of specialised cells, linking to tissues/organs and functional adaptation.
Demonstrate understanding of using percentile charts to monitor growth (interpreting percentiles, comparing an individual's measurement to population distribution, tracking changes over time).

Describe the function of embryonic stem cells, stem cells in animals, and meristems in plants (undifferentiated cells capable of division and differentiation; role in growth/repair and plant growth regions).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Stem cells in medicine: benefits and risks
Sub_topics.description: Discuss potential benefits and risks of using stem cells in medicine, including therapeutic potential (replacement cells/tissues) and risks (e.g. tumour formation, immune rejection, infection) and ethical considerations where relevant.

Explain the structure and function of sensory receptors, sensory neurones, relay neurones in the CNS, motor neurones and synapses in transmitting electrical impulses. Include neurone parts (axon, dendron, myelin sheath) and the role of neurotransmitters in synaptic transmission (chemical diffusion across synapse, receptor binding, triggering new impulse).
Explain the structure and function of a reflex arc including sensory, relay and motor neurones, and the pathway via the CNS for rapid, automatic responses.

Explain the role of meiotic cell division in sexual reproduction, including production of four daughter cells each with half the number of chromosomes, resulting in genetically different haploid gametes. Note: detailed stages of meiosis are not required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: DNA structure (double helix, base pairing, nucleotides)
Sub_topics.description: Describe DNA as a polymer made of: two strands coiled into a double helix; strands linked by complementary base pairs joined by weak hydrogen bonds; nucleotides consisting of a sugar and phosphate group with one of four bases attached to the sugar.
Describe the genome as the entire DNA of an organism; describe a gene as a section of a DNA molecule that codes for a specific protein (link to inheritance and phenotype via protein function).
Explain how DNA can be extracted from fruit (cell lysis, detergents/salt, filtering, precipitation with cold alcohol) at a conceptual method level.
Explain why there are differences in inherited characteristics as a result of different alleles (alternative versions of genes) and their effects on protein expression/traits.
Explain the terms: chromosome, gene, allele, dominant, recessive, homozygous, heterozygous, genotype, phenotype, gamete and zygote. Use terms correctly in inheritance contexts.
Explain monohybrid inheritance using genetic diagrams, Punnett squares and family pedigrees. Include genotype/phenotype relationships for dominant and recessive alleles and expected offspring ratios.
Describe how the sex of offspring is determined at fertilisation using genetic diagrams (X and Y chromosomes; egg always X; sperm X or Y; XX female, XY male).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Probabilities, ratios and percentages in inheritance
Sub_topics.description: Calculate and analyse outcomes from monohybrid crosses and pedigree analysis for dominant and recessive traits using probabilities, ratios and percentages; interpret results in terms of expected vs observed outcomes.
State that most phenotypic features result from multiple genes rather than single-gene inheritance, contributing to continuous variation.

Describe causes of variation influencing phenotype: (a) genetic variation due to mutation and sexual reproduction; (b) environmental variation due to an organism’s environment (acquired characteristics).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Human Genome Project: outcomes and applications
Sub_topics.description: Discuss outcomes of the Human Genome Project and potential applications within medicine (e.g. identifying genes linked to disease, personalised medicine, improved diagnosis/treatments) and associated considerations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Genetic variation in populations and mutation
Sub_topics.description: State that there is usually extensive genetic variation within a population of a species and that variation arises through mutations.
State that most genetic mutations have no effect on phenotype, some have a small effect, and rarely a single mutation significantly affects phenotype.

Topics.Topic_name: Topic 4 – Natural selection and genetic modification

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Charles Darwin’s theory of evolution by natural selection
Sub_topics.description: Explain Charles Darwin’s theory of evolution by natural selection: variation within populations, competition/selection pressures, differential survival and reproduction, inheritance of advantageous alleles, and gradual change in populations over generations leading to adaptation/speciation.

Explain how emergence of resistant organisms supports Darwin’s theory of evolution by natural selection, including antibiotic resistance in bacteria (mutation/variation, selection by antibiotic use, survival and reproduction of resistant bacteria, spread of resistance).

Describe evidence for human evolution based on fossils, including: Ardi (4.4 million years ago), Lucy (3.2 million years ago), and Richard Leakey’s discovery of fossils from 1.6 million years ago. Include using fossil record features and dating context to support evolutionary timelines.
Describe evidence for human evolution based on stone tools, including development of tools over time and how tools can be dated from their environment (stratigraphy/context dating).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Three domains classification from genetic analysis
Sub_topics.description: Describe how genetic analysis has led to the suggestion of the three domains classification method (Bacteria, Archaea, Eukaryota) rather than the five kingdoms system; link to molecular evidence and evolutionary relationships.

Explain selective breeding (artificial selection) and its impact on food plants and domesticated animals, including selecting parents with desired traits, breeding over generations, and potential issues such as reduced gene pool/inbreeding.
Describe genetic engineering as modifying the genome of an organism to introduce desirable characteristics (transfer of genes between organisms), distinguishing it from selective breeding.

Describe main stages of genetic engineering including use of restriction enzymes (cut DNA at specific sequences), ligase (joins DNA fragments), sticky ends (complementary overhangs enabling insertion), and vectors (e.g. plasmids/viruses used to transfer genes into host cells).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evaluate benefits and risks of genetic engineering and selective breeding
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate benefits and risks of genetic engineering and selective breeding in modern agriculture and medicine, including practical implications (yield, disease resistance, pharmaceuticals), ethical considerations, environmental impacts, and issues of safety/long-term effects.

Topics.Topic_name: Topic 5 – Health, disease and the development of medicines

Sub_topics.description: Describe health as a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity, as defined by the World Health Organization (WHO).

Describe the difference between communicable diseases (infectious, caused by pathogens and transmissible) and non-communicable diseases (not caused by pathogens; generally not transmissible; often lifestyle/genetic/environment interaction).
Explain why presence of one disease can lead to higher susceptibility to other diseases (e.g. immune system weakened, barriers compromised, co-infections).
Describe a pathogen as a disease-causing organism, including viruses, bacteria, fungi and protists; link pathogen type to mode of action.

Describe common infections and their effects: cholera (bacteria) causes diarrhoea; tuberculosis (bacteria) causes lung damage; Chalara ash dieback (fungi) causes leaf loss and bark lesions; malaria (protists) causes damage to blood and liver; HIV (virus) destroys white blood cells leading to onset of AIDS.

Explain how pathogens are spread and how spread can be reduced/prevented, including: cholera—water; tuberculosis—airborne; Chalara ash dieback—airborne; malaria—animal vectors. Include control measures (hygiene, sanitation, isolation, vaccination where applicable, vector control).

Explain how sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are spread and how spread can be reduced/prevented, including Chlamydia (bacteria) and HIV (virus); include barrier contraception, testing, treatment, education.
Describe how physical barriers and chemical defences protect the body from pathogens, including: physical barriers (mucus, cilia, skin) and chemical defences (lysozymes, hydrochloric acid).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Specific immune system: antibodies and memory cells
Sub_topics.description: Explain the role of the specific immune system in defence: exposure to pathogen; antigens trigger immune response causing production of antibodies; antigens also trigger production of memory lymphocytes; memory lymphocytes enable faster, stronger secondary response upon re-exposure.

Explain the body’s response to immunisation using an inactive form of a pathogen, including antigen exposure, antibody production, and memory lymphocyte formation leading to immunity and faster secondary response.

Explain that antibiotics can only be used to treat bacterial infections because they inhibit cell processes in bacteria but not in the host organism; distinguish from viruses (no independent metabolism).

Describe that developing new medicines, including antibiotics, has many stages: discovery, development, preclinical testing, and clinical testing; include purpose of each stage (safety, dosage, efficacy, side effects).

Describe that many non-communicable diseases are caused by interaction of multiple factors, including cardiovascular diseases, many cancers, some lung and liver diseases, and diseases influenced by nutrition (genetics, lifestyle, environment).

Explain effects of lifestyle factors on non-communicable diseases at local, national and global levels, including: exercise and diet on obesity and malnutrition; using BMI and waist:hip calculations. Use BMI equation: BMI = mass (kg) / (height (m))². Also include: alcohol on liver diseases; smoking on cardiovascular diseases.

Evaluate treatments for cardiovascular disease including: life-long medication, surgical procedures, and lifestyle changes. Consider effectiveness, risks, costs, accessibility, and long-term outcomes using data where provided.

Topics.Topic_name: Topic 6 – Plant structures and their functions

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Photosynthetic organisms as producers and biomass
Sub_topics.description: Describe photosynthetic organisms as the main producers of food and therefore biomass in ecosystems/food chains, linking to energy capture and transfer through trophic levels.

Describe photosynthesis in plants and algae as an endothermic reaction using light energy to react carbon dioxide and water to produce glucose and oxygen (word and symbol understanding at GCSE level).

Explain the effect of temperature, light intensity and carbon dioxide concentration as limiting factors on rate of photosynthesis; interpret typical limiting factor graphs and describe how limiting factors restrict rate.

Explain interactions of temperature, light intensity and carbon dioxide concentration in limiting rate of photosynthesis (more than one factor can limit; changing one factor may only increase rate until another becomes limiting).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical: Light intensity and photosynthesis rate
Sub_topics.description: Core Practical: Investigate effect of light intensity on rate of photosynthesis using algal balls (or similar). Set up at varying distances from a light source to change light intensity; measure rate (e.g. oxygen production/indicator change) and compare with distance; control variables such as temperature and CO₂ availability.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Inverse square law and light intensity in photosynthesis
Sub_topics.description: Explain that rate of photosynthesis is directly proportional to light intensity and that light intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from a light source. Use inverse square law calculations to relate intensity ∝ 1/d² and apply to data/problems.

Explain how structure of root hair cells is adapted to absorb water and mineral ions (large surface area via hair, thin cell wall, large vacuole/low water potential, many mitochondria for active transport of ions).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Xylem and phloem structure and function
Sub_topics.description: Explain adaptations of xylem and phloem: xylem—lignified dead cells forming tubes for water/mineral transport and support; phloem—living cells transporting sucrose by translocation using energy (ATP) and companion cells conceptually.

Explain how water and mineral ions are transported through plant by transpiration, including structure and function of stomata (gas exchange openings; guard cells; role in water vapour loss driving transpiration stream).
Describe how sucrose is transported around the plant by translocation in phloem from sources (leaves) to sinks (roots, fruits, storage tissues).
Explain effects of environmental factors on rate of water uptake by a plant: light intensity, air movement (wind), and temperature; link to transpiration rate via evaporation and diffusion gradients.

Demonstrate understanding of rate calculations for transpiration/water uptake, using appropriate measurements (e.g. volume uptake per time, bubble movement in potometer) and graph interpretation where relevant.

Topics.Topic_name: Topic 7 – Animal coordination, control and homeostasis

Sub_topics.description: Describe where hormones are produced and how they are transported from endocrine glands to target organs, including pituitary gland, thyroid gland, pancreas, adrenal glands, ovaries and testes; hormones carried in blood plasma to target cells with receptors.

Explain that adrenaline is produced by adrenal glands to prepare body for fight or flight, including: increased heart rate; increased blood pressure; increased blood flow to muscles; raised blood sugar levels by stimulating liver to convert glycogen to glucose.

Explain how thyroxine controls metabolic rate as an example of negative feedback: low thyroxine stimulates TRH release from hypothalamus; TRH triggers TSH release from pituitary; TSH stimulates thyroid to produce thyroxine; normal thyroxine levels inhibit TRH release and TSH production (homeostatic loop).
Describe stages of menstrual cycle, including roles of oestrogen and progesterone in control of cycle (uterus lining build-up/maintenance and shedding). Interpret cycle timing qualitatively.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hormone interactions in menstrual cycle (FSH, LH)
Sub_topics.description: Explain interactions of oestrogen, progesterone, FSH and LH in controlling menstrual cycle, including repair and maintenance of uterus wall, ovulation, and menstruation; include feedback interactions and timing of hormone peaks.

Explain how hormonal contraception influences menstrual cycle and prevents pregnancy (e.g. suppressing FSH/LH to prevent ovulation; thickening cervical mucus; altering uterus lining), at appropriate GCSE level.
Evaluate hormonal and barrier methods of contraception, considering effectiveness, side effects, STI protection, user dependence, and ethical/social considerations.

Explain use of hormones in Assisted Reproductive Technology (ART) including IVF and clomifene therapy (stimulating ovulation, controlling cycle, supporting implantation), and outline basic steps of IVF.
Explain importance of maintaining a constant internal environment (homeostasis) in response to internal and external change, ensuring optimal conditions for enzymes and cell function.
Explain how insulin controls blood glucose concentration (released by pancreas; increases glucose uptake by cells; stimulates glycogen formation in liver/muscle), as part of negative feedback.
Explain how blood glucose concentration is regulated by glucagon (released when glucose low; stimulates glycogen breakdown to glucose in liver; raises blood glucose), complementing insulin control.

Explain cause of type 1 diabetes (little/no insulin production due to autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells) and how it is controlled (insulin injections/pumps, monitoring, diet management).

Explain cause of type 2 diabetes (insulin resistance and/or insufficient insulin production; often linked to obesity/inactivity) and how it is controlled (diet, exercise, weight loss, medication; sometimes insulin).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Body mass correlation with type 2 diabetes (BMI, waist:hip)
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate correlation between body mass and type 2 diabetes including waist:hip calculations and BMI, using BMI = mass (kg) / (height (m))²; interpret scatter/graphical data and distinguish correlation from causation.

Topics.Topic_name: Topic 8 – Exchange and transport in animals

Sub_topics.description: Describe the need to transport substances into and out of organisms, including oxygen, carbon dioxide, water, dissolved food molecules, mineral ions and urea; link to metabolism, respiration, and excretion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Exchange surfaces and transport systems; surface area:volume
Sub_topics.description: Explain need for exchange surfaces and transport systems in multicellular organisms (short diffusion distances, maintaining gradients) including calculation of surface area : volume ratio and linking high SA:V to faster exchange.

Explain how alveoli are adapted for gas exchange by diffusion between air in lungs and blood in capillaries (large surface area, thin walls, moist surface, good blood supply/ventilation maintaining concentration gradients).

Explain how structure of blood relates to function: red blood cells (biconcave, haemoglobin, no nucleus for O₂ transport); white blood cells (phagocytes engulf pathogens; lymphocytes produce antibodies/memory cells); plasma transports dissolved substances; platelets and clotting role.

Explain how structure of blood vessels relates to function (arteries thick muscular/elastic walls for high pressure; veins wider lumen with valves; capillaries thin walls one cell thick for diffusion).

Explain how structure of heart and circulatory system relates to function, including major blood vessels, valves preventing backflow, and relative thickness of chamber walls (left ventricle thicker). Include double circulation conceptually.

Describe cellular respiration as an exothermic reaction occurring continuously in living cells to release energy for metabolic processes; include aerobic and anaerobic respiration as contexts (no detailed equations required beyond GCSE expectations).
Compare aerobic respiration with anaerobic respiration (oxygen requirement, energy yield, products such as CO₂ and H₂O vs lactic acid in animals; link to exercise and oxygen debt conceptually).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical: Respiration rate in living organisms (respirometer)
Sub_topics.description: Core Practical: Investigate rate of respiration in living organisms using a simple respirometer. Use soda lime to absorb CO₂, cotton wool barrier, organisms, capillary tube with coloured liquid; measure movement over time to determine O₂ consumption. Carry out using water bath at different temperatures; consider ethical handling and safety. Analyse rate from distance/volume change per time.
Calculate heart rate, stroke volume and cardiac output using: cardiac output = stroke volume × heart rate. Apply to data and unit conversions where needed.
Describe levels of organisation: individual organism, population, community, and whole ecosystem; use terms correctly when describing ecological structure.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Abiotic and biotic factors affecting communities
Sub_topics.description: Explain how communities can be affected by abiotic factors (temperature, light, water, pollutants) and biotic factors (competition, predation). Link factors to population size/distribution and adaptations.
Describe importance of interdependence in a community (food webs, mutual reliance for resources, stability, impacts of removing species).
Describe how survival of some organisms depends on other species, including parasitism (one benefits, host harmed) and mutualism (both benefit), with suitable examples.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical: Fieldwork (quadrats and belt transects)
Sub_topics.description: Core Practical: Investigate relationship between organisms and their environment using field-work techniques including quadrats and belt transects. Use belt transect along a gradient (e.g. shade to no shade); plan sampling, identify/observe organisms/plants, record abundance/distribution systematically, consider random vs systematic sampling, and evaluate limitations and improvements.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Estimating population size from fieldwork data
Sub_topics.description: Explain how to determine number of organisms in a given area using raw data from quadrats and belt transects (e.g. mean per quadrat × total area/quadrat area), including using appropriate sampling to get representative estimates and considering uncertainty.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Human interactions in ecosystems and biodiversity impacts
Sub_topics.description: Explain positive and negative human interactions within ecosystems and impacts on biodiversity, including fish farming, introduction of non-indigenous species, and eutrophication. Include mechanisms and consequences such as oxygen depletion and species loss.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Benefits of maintaining biodiversity and conservation
Sub_topics.description: Explain benefits of maintaining local and global biodiversity, including conservation of animal species and impact of reforestation; link to ecosystem resilience, resources, and climate regulation.
Describe how different materials cycle through abiotic and biotic components of an ecosystem (movement of elements/compounds between organisms, atmosphere, soil, water).

Explain importance of carbon cycle, including processes involved (photosynthesis, respiration, decomposition, combustion) and role of microorganisms as decomposers returning carbon compounds to environment.

Explain importance of water cycle (evaporation, condensation, precipitation, runoff, transpiration) including processes involved and production of potable water in drought areas, including desalination.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nitrates availability and nitrogen cycle role of bacteria
Sub_topics.description: Explain how nitrates are made available for plant uptake, including use of fertilisers, crop rotation, and role of bacteria in nitrogen cycle (nitrogen fixation, nitrification conceptually) to replenish soil nitrates.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Recall formulae of elements, compounds and ions
Sub_topics.description: Recall formulae of elements, simple compounds and ions (including common diatomic elements where relevant and common ion charges used in GCSE Combined Science chemistry).
Write word equations to represent chemical reactions, using correct reactant and product names.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Balanced chemical equations with state symbols
Sub_topics.description: Write balanced chemical equations, including correct use of state symbols (s), (l), (g) and (aq). Include balancing atoms and understanding conservation of mass.
Write balanced ionic equations for reactions in solution where appropriate, showing spectator ions removed and charges/atoms balanced.
Describe use of hazard symbols on containers: indicating dangers associated with contents and informing safe-working precautions in the laboratory; interpret common GHS symbols at GCSE level.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Risk assessment and precautions in practicals
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate risks in a practical procedure and suggest suitable precautions for a range of practicals (including those in this specification), considering hazards, exposure routes, control measures, and safe disposal.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Dalton model and discovery of subatomic particles
Sub_topics.description: Describe how the Dalton model of the atom has changed over time due to discovery of subatomic particles, leading to modern nuclear/planetary models.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Atomic structure: nucleus and electron shells
Sub_topics.description: Describe structure of atom as a nucleus containing protons and neutrons, surrounded by electrons in shells (energy levels).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Relative charge and mass of subatomic particles
Sub_topics.description: Recall relative charge and relative mass of a proton, neutron and electron (proton +1 mass 1; neutron 0 mass 1; electron −1 mass ~1/1836).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Neutral atoms: equal protons and electrons
Sub_topics.description: Explain why atoms contain equal numbers of protons and electrons, resulting in overall neutral charge.
Describe nucleus as very small compared with overall size of atom; relate to scale and evidence (e.g. scattering).
Recall that most of the mass of an atom is concentrated in the nucleus (protons and neutrons).
Recall meaning of mass number (total number of protons + neutrons; nucleon number).
Describe atoms of a given element as having same number of protons; this proton/atomic number is unique to the element.
Describe isotopes as atoms of same element with same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons in nuclei; link to mass differences and similar chemical properties.
Calculate numbers of protons, neutrons and electrons in atoms given atomic number and mass number; include neutrons = mass number − atomic number; electrons = atomic number for neutral atoms.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Relative atomic mass and isotopic abundance
Sub_topics.description: Explain how existence of isotopes results in relative atomic masses of some elements not being whole numbers because values are weighted means of isotopic masses based on natural abundance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Calculate relative atomic mass from isotopes
Sub_topics.description: Calculate relative atomic mass from relative masses and abundances of isotopes using weighted mean: Ar = Σ(isotopic mass × abundance) / Σ(abundance); apply to percent or ratio data with correct significant figures.
Describe how Dmitri Mendeleev arranged elements known at the time in a periodic table using properties of elements and their compounds, placing similar properties together and leaving gaps.
Describe how Dmitri Mendeleev used his table to predict existence and properties of elements not yet discovered (using gaps and trends).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Atomic mass order not always correct in Mendeleev table
Sub_topics.description: Explain that Mendeleev thought he arranged elements in increasing relative atomic mass but this was not always true due to relative abundance of isotopes for some pairs; link to modern atomic number basis.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Atomic number meaning and periodic table position
Sub_topics.description: Explain meaning of atomic number in terms of periodic table position and number of protons in nucleus.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Periods and groups in modern periodic table
Sub_topics.description: Describe periodic table arrangement: elements in order of increasing atomic number in rows called periods; elements with similar properties in vertical columns called groups.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Metals and non-metals by position and structure
Sub_topics.description: Identify elements as metals or non-metals according to position in periodic table; explain division in terms of atomic structure/electron configurations and typical property differences.
Predict electronic configurations of first 20 elements as shell diagrams and in numeric form (e.g. 2.8.1). Link to atomic number and filling of shells.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electronic configuration and periodic table position
Sub_topics.description: Explain how electronic configuration relates to position in periodic table (period = number of occupied shells; group (main groups) relates to number of outer electrons and hence properties).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ionic bonding: electron transfer and dot-cross
Sub_topics.description: Explain how ionic bonds form by transfer of electrons between atoms producing cations and anions; represent using dot and cross diagrams showing electron transfer and resulting charges.
Recall that an ion is an atom or group of atoms with a positive or negative charge (due to electron loss/gain).
Calculate numbers of protons, neutrons and electrons in simple ions given atomic number and mass number, accounting for charge (electrons = atomic number ± charge).
Explain formation of ions in ionic compounds from atoms of elements in groups 1, 2, 6 and 7 (e.g. Na⁺, Mg²⁺, O²⁻, Cl⁻) in terms of electron configurations and achieving full outer shells.
Explain use of endings -ide (binary compounds) and -ate (compounds containing oxygen, polyatomic ions) in naming compounds.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Formulae of ionic compounds from ions
Sub_topics.description: Deduce formulae of ionic compounds (including oxides, hydroxides, halides, nitrates, carbonates, sulfates) given formulae/charges of constituent ions; use charge balancing and simplest whole-number ratios.

Explain structure of ionic compound as a giant lattice: regular arrangement of ions held by strong electrostatic forces (ionic bonds) between oppositely charged ions; link to melting point and conductivity properties conceptually.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Covalent bonding: shared pair of electrons
Sub_topics.description: Explain how a covalent bond forms when a pair of electrons is shared between two atoms, achieving full outer shells in simple molecules.
Recall that covalent bonding results in formation of molecules (small groups of atoms held by covalent bonds).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Typical size of atoms and small molecules (order of magnitude)
Sub_topics.description: Recall typical size (order of magnitude) of atoms and small molecules; use to compare scales and interpret diagrams (e.g. ~10⁻¹⁰ m for atoms).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Dot-cross diagrams for simple covalent substances
Sub_topics.description: Explain formation of simple molecular covalent substances using dot and cross diagrams: hydrogen (H₂), hydrogen chloride (HCl), water (H₂O), methane (CH₄), oxygen (O₂), carbon dioxide (CO₂). Show shared electron pairs and outer shell completion (including double bonds where relevant).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Classifying substances by bonding/structure and properties
Sub_topics.description: Explain classification of elements/compounds as ionic, simple molecular (covalent), giant covalent, or metallic, and how structure/bonding leads to different physical properties: relative melting/boiling points, relative solubility in water, electrical conductivity as solids and in solution (or molten for ionic).

Explain properties of ionic compounds: high melting/boiling points due to strong electrostatic forces; electrical conductivity (do not conduct as solids because ions fixed; conduct when molten or aqueous because ions mobile).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Properties of simple covalent molecular substances
Sub_topics.description: Explain properties of typical simple covalent molecular compounds: low melting/boiling points due to weak intermolecular forces; poor electrical conductivity due to lack of free ions/electrons.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Graphite and diamond as carbon allotropes (giant covalent)
Sub_topics.description: Recall that graphite and diamond are different forms (allotropes) of carbon and are examples of giant covalent substances.
Describe structures of diamond and graphite (diamond: each carbon bonded to 4 others in tetrahedral network; graphite: each carbon bonded to 3 others in layers with delocalised electrons).

Explain, using structure and bonding, why graphite is used for electrodes and as a lubricant (delocalised electrons conduct; layers slide), whereas diamond is used in cutting tools (very hard due to 3D covalent network).
Explain properties of fullerenes including C₆₀ and graphene in terms of structure and bonding (molecular/giant structures, delocalised electrons, strength, conductivity, surface area).
Describe that simple polymers consist of large molecules containing chains of carbon atoms, using poly(ethene) as example (repeating units, long chain).
Explain properties of metals including malleability and ability to conduct electricity in terms of metallic bonding (lattice of positive ions with delocalised electrons).

Describe limitations of representations/models including dot and cross, ball-and-stick, and 2D/3D representations; recognise they may not show true sizes, angles, electron clouds, or intermolecular forces.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Typical properties of metals vs non-metals
Sub_topics.description: Describe most metals as shiny solids with high melting points, high density, and good electrical conductivity, whereas most non-metals have low boiling points and are poor conductors of electricity; understand exceptions exist.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Relative formula mass and percentage composition
Sub_topics.description: Calculate: (a) relative formula mass (Mr) given relative atomic masses (Ar); (b) percentage by mass of an element in a compound using Ar values and Mr: % = (total Ar of element in formula ÷ Mr) × 100.
Calculate formulae of simple compounds from reacting masses or percentage composition; understand results are empirical formulae (simplest whole-number ratios).
Deduce: (a) empirical formula from molecular formula; (b) molecular formula from empirical formula and relative molecular mass (Mr) using multiplier = Mr / empirical formula mass.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Experiment: empirical formula of magnesium oxide
Sub_topics.description: Describe an experiment to determine empirical formula of a simple compound such as magnesium oxide (weigh Mg, heat in oxygen, reweigh MgO; calculate moles and simplest ratio; consider oxidation, avoiding product loss, and repeated heating to constant mass).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Conservation of mass in closed and open systems
Sub_topics.description: Explain law of conservation of mass applied to: (a) closed systems (e.g. precipitation reaction in closed flask) where total mass stays constant; (b) non-enclosed/open systems where gas enters or leaves so measured mass may change though total mass including gases is conserved.
Calculate masses of reactants/products from balanced chemical equations given mass of one substance (stoichiometry using molar ratios and relative masses).
Calculate concentration of solutions in g dm⁻³ using concentration = mass of solute (g) ÷ volume of solution (dm³). Convert cm³ to dm³ (1000 cm³ = 1 dm³) as needed.

Recall that one mole is: (a) the Avogadro constant number of particles (6.02 × 10²³ atoms, molecules, formulae or ions); (b) a mass of ‘relative particle mass’ in grams (molar mass concept). Use standard form for Avogadro constant.

Calculate numbers of: (a) moles in a given mass and vice versa using n = m/M; (b) particles in a given number of moles and vice versa using N = n × 6.02 × 10²³; (c) particles in a given mass and vice versa by combining the above. Use correct units and significant figures.
Explain why mass of product formed is controlled by mass of reactant not in excess (the limiting reactant); relate to stoichiometric ratios and completion when limiting reactant used up.

Deduce stoichiometry of a reaction from masses of reactants and products by converting masses to moles and comparing mole ratios to simplest whole numbers; use to infer balanced equation relationships.

Topics.Topic_name: Topic 2 – States of matter and mixtures

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Particle model of solids, liquids and gases
Sub_topics.description: Describe arrangement, movement and relative energy of particles in solids, liquids and gases (solid: close packed, vibrate, low energy; liquid: close, random, slide, medium energy; gas: far apart, random fast, high energy).

Recall names for interconversions between states of matter (melting, freezing, evaporation, condensation, boiling, sublimation) and recognise these are physical changes, contrasted with chemical reactions that form new substances.

Explain changes in particle arrangement, movement and energy during interconversions (heating increases kinetic energy, overcomes intermolecular forces; cooling decreases energy and forms more ordered arrangements).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Predict state from conditions and data
Sub_topics.description: Predict physical state of a substance under specified conditions using suitable data (e.g. melting/boiling points) and relate to temperature/pressure conditions.
Explain difference between 'pure' in chemistry vs everyday use; distinguish a pure substance (single element/compound) from a mixture (physical combination).
Interpret melting point data to distinguish pure substances (sharp melting point) from mixtures/impure substances (melt over a range).

Explain types of mixtures separated by: simple distillation, fractional distillation, filtration, crystallisation, paper chromatography; link to differences in boiling point, solubility, particle size, and adsorption/solubility in phases.
Describe an appropriate experimental technique to separate a mixture given properties of components (solubility, boiling point, miscibility, insoluble solids, dyes).

Describe paper chromatography as separating mixtures of soluble substances by running a solvent (mobile phase) through the mixture on paper containing stationary phase, causing components to move at different rates/distances.

Interpret paper chromatograms: distinguish pure vs impure (single vs multiple spots); identify substances by comparison with known samples; calculate and use Rf values (Rf = distance moved by substance ÷ distance moved by solvent front) to identify substances.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical: Distillation and chromatography of inks
Sub_topics.description: Core Practical (two parts): (1) produce chromatogram of dyes in ink using paper chromatography; (2) use simple distillation apparatus to separate pure water from ink. Include safe use of Bunsen burner/heating, correct set-up of distillation (condenser, collection), handling liquids, and interpreting outputs (chromatogram spots, recovered distillate).

Describe how: (a) waste and ground water can be made potable (sedimentation, filtration, chlorination); (b) sea water can be made potable by distillation; (c) water used in analysis must not contain dissolved salts (use distilled/deionised water).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Acids and alkalis as ion sources
Sub_topics.description: Recall that acids in solution are sources of hydrogen ions (H⁺) and alkalis in solution are sources of hydroxide ions (OH⁻).
Recall that neutral solution has pH 7; acidic solutions have pH < 7; alkaline solutions have pH > 7.
Recall effect of acids and alkalis on indicators including litmus, methyl orange and phenolphthalein (colour changes in acidic/alkaline conditions).

Recall that higher concentration of hydrogen ions in an acidic solution gives lower pH; higher concentration of hydroxide ions in an alkaline solution gives higher pH; link to logarithmic nature conceptually.
Recall that when hydrogen ion concentration increases by factor of 10, pH decreases by 1 (log₁₀ relationship). Apply to simple reasoning problems.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical: pH change in neutralisation (Ca(OH)₂/CaO + HCl)
Sub_topics.description: Core Practical: Investigate change in pH on adding powdered calcium hydroxide or calcium oxide to a fixed volume of dilute hydrochloric acid. Add measured increments of solid to fixed acid volume; record pH at intervals using pH meter or universal indicator paper (sampling with glass rod); plot/interpret pH change trend and neutralisation point; consider variables and safe handling of corrosive substances.
Explain terms dilute and concentrated with respect to amount of substance in solution (concentration; not same as weak/strong).
Explain terms weak and strong acids with respect to degree of dissociation into ions in water (partial vs complete ionisation).
Recall that a base is any substance that reacts with an acid to form a salt and water only.
Recall that alkalis are soluble bases (produce OH⁻ in solution).

Explain general reactions of aqueous acids with: metals, metal oxides, metal hydroxides, and metal carbonates to produce salts (and often hydrogen or carbon dioxide). Use word/symbol equations where required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Tests for hydrogen and carbon dioxide
Sub_topics.description: Describe chemical test for hydrogen (lighted splint gives squeaky pop) and carbon dioxide (turns limewater milky/cloudy).
Describe neutralisation as reaction between an acid and a base.
Explain acid-alkali neutralisation as reaction where H⁺ ions from acid react with OH⁻ ions from alkali to form water (H⁺ + OH⁻ → H₂O).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Preparing soluble salts from acids and insoluble reactants
Sub_topics.description: Explain why when preparing soluble salts from an acid and an insoluble reactant: excess reactant is added (to use all acid); excess is removed by filtration; remaining solution contains only salt and water (then crystallised).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Preparing soluble salts from acids and soluble reactants (titration)
Sub_topics.description: Explain why preparing soluble salts from acid and soluble reactant requires titration to find exact neutralisation point; then mix in correct proportions; remaining solution after reaction is only salt and water (then crystallised).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical: Prepare hydrated copper sulfate crystals
Sub_topics.description: Core Practical: Prepare pure, dry hydrated copper sulfate crystals from copper oxide. Warm dilute sulfuric acid using a water bath; add excess copper oxide; filter to remove unreacted solid; evaporate filtrate using evaporating basin and Bunsen burner; allow to crystallise; dry crystals using watch glass. Emphasise purity, safe heating, and correct technique.

Describe how to carry out acid-alkali titration using burette, pipette and suitable indicator to prepare pure, dry salt: accurate volume measurement, endpoint detection, repeat concordant titres, and crystallisation of salt.

Recall general solubility rules: all common Na⁺, K⁺, NH₄⁺ salts soluble; all nitrates soluble; common chlorides soluble except Ag⁺ and Pb²⁺; common sulfates soluble except Pb²⁺, Ba²⁺, Ca²⁺; common carbonates and hydroxides insoluble except Na⁺, K⁺, NH₄⁺.
Predict whether precipitate forms when named solutions mixed; name precipitate if formed, using solubility rules and correct chemical formulae.
Describe method to prepare pure, dry sample of insoluble salt (mix solutions to precipitate, filter, wash with distilled water, dry).
Recall electrolytes are ionic compounds in molten state or dissolved in water (mobile ions allow conduction).
Describe electrolysis as process where electrical energy from a direct current supply decomposes electrolytes (causes chemical change).
Explain movement of ions during electrolysis: cations migrate to negative cathode; anions migrate to positive anode.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Products of electrolysis with inert electrodes (specified electrolytes)
Sub_topics.description: Explain formation of products in electrolysis using inert electrodes for: copper chloride solution, sodium chloride solution, sodium sulfate solution, acidified water (sulfuric acid), and molten lead bromide (demonstration). Include discharge rules conceptually (H₂ at cathode for aqueous unless less reactive metal ions; halogens at anode for halide solutions; O₂ at anode from sulfate/water).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Predict electrolysis products (molten binary ionic compounds)
Sub_topics.description: Predict products of electrolysis of other binary ionic compounds in molten state (metal at cathode, non-metal at anode) based on ion charges and electron transfer.
Write half equations for reactions at anode and cathode in electrolysis, balancing atoms and charge with electrons (e⁻).
Explain oxidation and reduction in terms of loss (oxidation) or gain (reduction) of electrons (OILRIG).
Recall that reduction occurs at cathode and oxidation occurs at anode in electrolysis reactions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electrolysis of CuSO₄ with copper electrodes (purification)
Sub_topics.description: Explain formation of products in electrolysis of copper sulfate solution using copper electrodes and how it can purify copper: copper dissolves at anode (Cu → Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻) and deposits at cathode (Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical: Electrolysis of copper sulfate (inert vs copper electrodes)
Sub_topics.description: Core Practical: Investigate electrolysis of copper sulfate solution with inert (graphite) electrodes and with copper electrodes. Include setting up circuit, identifying products with inert electrodes, and quantitative analysis with copper electrodes (effect of current on mass changes of electrodes, link to charge/time). Emphasise accurate measurement and safety with electrical equipment/chemicals.
Deduce relative reactivity of metals from reactions with water, acids and salt solutions (displacement). Use observations such as fizzing, temperature change, and whether displacement occurs.
Explain displacement reactions as redox reactions in terms of gain or loss of electrons (more reactive metal loses electrons to form cations; less reactive metal ions gain electrons).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reactivity series and tendency to form cations
Sub_topics.description: Explain reactivity series (K, Na, Ca, Mg, Al, (C), Zn, Fe, (H), Cu, Ag, Au) in terms of metals’ reactions with water and dilute acids and their tendency for atoms to form cations (lose electrons).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Metals in Earth's crust (ores vs native)
Sub_topics.description: Recall that most metals are extracted from ores in Earth’s crust, whereas unreactive metals may be found as uncombined/native elements.
Explain oxidation as gain of oxygen and reduction as loss of oxygen (alternative redox definitions).
Recall that extraction of metals involves reduction of ores (removal of oxygen or gain of electrons).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Extraction method depends on reactivity and cost
Sub_topics.description: Explain why extraction method depends on metal’s position in reactivity series and cost, illustrated by: heating with carbon (including iron) for metals below carbon; electrolysis (including aluminium) for more reactive metals. Note: detailed blast furnace knowledge not required.

Evaluate alternative biological methods of metal extraction: bacterial extraction (bioleaching) and phytoextraction (using plants). Consider advantages/disadvantages such as rate, cost, energy, environmental impacts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Resistance to oxidation and reactivity series
Sub_topics.description: Explain how a metal’s relative resistance to oxidation is related to its position in reactivity series (less reactive = more resistant to corrosion/oxidation).
Evaluate advantages of recycling metals, including economic implications and how recycling preserves environment and supply of raw materials (reduces mining, energy use, waste).
Describe that life-cycle assessment considers environmental effects of obtaining raw materials, manufacturing, using, and disposing of product at end of life; understand trade-offs and assumptions.
Evaluate data from a life cycle assessment of a product to compare environmental impacts and justify choices; consider uncertainties and weighting of categories.
Recall that chemical reactions can be reversible; use symbol ⇌ in equations; understand direction can be altered by changing reaction conditions.
Explain dynamic equilibrium: in a closed system forward and reverse reactions continue at equal rates so concentrations remain constant over time.
Describe formation of ammonia as reversible reaction between nitrogen (from air) and hydrogen (from natural gas) and that system can reach dynamic equilibrium (Haber process context).
Recall Haber process conditions: temperature 450 °C, pressure 200 atmospheres, iron catalyst.

Predict how position of dynamic equilibrium is affected by changes in temperature, pressure and concentration; apply qualitative Le Chatelier’s principle to reversible reactions including Haber process examples.

Topics.Topic_name: Topic 6 – Groups in the periodic table

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Periodic table groups: alkali metals, halogens, noble gases
Sub_topics.description: Explain why some elements can be classified as alkali metals (group 1), halogens (group 7) or noble gases (group 0) based on their position in the periodic table and common properties linked to outer electron configuration.
Recall alkali metals are soft and have relatively low melting points compared to many other metals.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reactions of Li, Na, K with water
Sub_topics.description: Describe reactions of lithium, sodium and potassium with water (formation of metal hydroxide and hydrogen; increasing vigour down group; observable effects such as floating, fizzing, melting, flames).
Describe pattern in reactivity of alkali metals (Li, Na, K) with water and use to predict reactivity of other group 1 metals (increasing reactivity down group).
Explain group 1 reactivity trend in terms of electronic configurations (outer electron further from nucleus, more shielding, lower attraction, easier electron loss).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Halogen colours and states at room temperature
Sub_topics.description: Recall colours and physical states of chlorine, bromine and iodine at room temperature (Cl₂ green gas; Br₂ red-brown liquid; I₂ grey solid with purple vapour).

Describe pattern in physical properties of halogens (Cl, Br, I) and use to predict properties of other halogens (increasing melting/boiling points and density down group; state changes gas→liquid→solid).
Describe chemical test for chlorine (bleaches damp litmus paper; turns it white after initially red).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Halogens reacting with metals to form halides
Sub_topics.description: Describe reactions of chlorine, bromine and iodine with metals to form metal halides; use pattern to predict reactions of other halogens (reactivity decreases down group).
Recall that halogens form hydrogen halides which dissolve in water to form acidic solutions (e.g. HCl, HBr, HI); use pattern to predict for other halogens.

Describe relative reactivity of halogens (Cl₂ > Br₂ > I₂) shown by displacement reactions with halide ions in aqueous solution; use to predict reactions of astatine. Understand that more reactive halogen displaces less reactive halide from solution.

Explain why halogen displacement reactions are redox in terms of electron transfer; identify which substances are oxidised and which are reduced (halide ions oxidised to halogen; halogen reduced to halide).

Explain relative reactivity of halogens in terms of electronic configurations and ability to gain an electron; decreasing reactivity down group due to increased shielding and atomic radius reducing attraction for incoming electron.
Explain why noble gases are chemically inert compared with other elements in terms of full outer electron shells and stable electron configurations.
Explain how uses of noble gases depend on inertness, low density and/or non-flammability (e.g. helium balloons, argon in lamps/welding, neon lighting).
Describe pattern in physical properties of some noble gases and use it to predict physical properties of other noble gases (boiling points/density increase down group).

Topics.Topic_name: Topic 7 – Rates of reaction and energy changes

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical: Rates of reaction (gas volume and disappearing cross)
Sub_topics.description: Core Practical: Investigate effects of changing conditions on rates by (a) measuring gas production in reaction of hydrochloric acid with marble chips (collect volume over time; vary concentration/temperature/surface area); (b) observing colour/visibility change in sodium thiosulfate + hydrochloric acid using 'disappearing cross' method, including performing at different temperatures (warming thiosulfate). Plot and analyse graphs to determine rate and how it changes with conditions.

Suggest practical methods for determining rate of a given reaction (e.g. gas volume, mass loss, colour change, precipitate formation, pH change), including choice of measurable variable and time measurement.
Explain that reactions occur when particles collide and that rate increases when frequency and/or energy of collisions increases; link to successful collisions overcoming activation energy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Factors affecting rate (T, concentration, SA:V, pressure)
Sub_topics.description: Explain effects on rates of reaction of changes in temperature, concentration, surface area to volume ratio of a solid, and pressure (for gases) in terms of collision frequency and/or energy. Include qualitative proportional reasoning and SA:V concepts.
Interpret graphs of mass, volume or concentration of reactant/product against time, including identifying changing rate, completion, and comparing rates between conditions.
Describe a catalyst as substance that speeds up rate of reaction without altering products, remaining chemically unchanged and same mass at end of reaction.
Explain how adding a catalyst increases rate in terms of activation energy (provides alternative pathway with lower activation energy).
Recall enzymes are biological catalysts and are used in production of alcoholic drinks (e.g. yeast enzymes catalysing fermentation).

Recall that changes in heat energy accompany salts dissolving in water, neutralisation reactions, displacement reactions and precipitation reactions; when in solution, temperature changes can be measured to reflect heat changes.
Describe an exothermic change/reaction as one in which heat energy is given out to surroundings (temperature rises).
Describe an endothermic change/reaction as one in which heat energy is taken in from surroundings (temperature falls).
Recall breaking bonds is endothermic and making bonds is exothermic; link to energy profile concept.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Overall energy change and bond energies
Sub_topics.description: Recall overall heat energy change: exothermic if more energy released forming product bonds than required breaking reactant bonds; endothermic if less energy released than absorbed. Apply to explanations of reactions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Calculate reaction energy change from bond energies
Sub_topics.description: Calculate energy change using bond energies (kJ mol⁻¹): ΔH ≈ Σ(bonds broken) − Σ(bonds formed). Interpret sign (positive endothermic, negative exothermic).
Explain term activation energy as minimum energy needed for particles to react on collision; link to rate and temperature/catalysts.
Draw and label reaction profiles for endothermic and exothermic reactions, identifying reactants/products energy levels, activation energy, and overall energy change (ΔH direction).
Recall that hydrocarbons are compounds containing carbon and hydrogen only.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Crude oil as mixture, resource and feedstock
Sub_topics.description: Describe crude oil as a complex mixture of hydrocarbons; molecules have carbon chains or rings (specific ring structures not required); crude oil is important source of fuels and petrochemical feedstock; it is a finite resource.
Describe and explain separation of crude oil into fractions by fractional distillation (heating, vapourisation, condensation at different heights due to boiling point differences).
Recall names and uses of fractions: gases (domestic heating/cooking), petrol (cars), kerosene (aircraft), diesel oil (cars/trains), fuel oil (ships/power stations), bitumen (roads/roofs).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Differences between fractions (chain length and properties)
Sub_topics.description: Explain how hydrocarbons in different fractions differ in number of C and H atoms (chain length), boiling points, ease of ignition (flammability), viscosity; recognise most are alkanes in homologous series.

Explain homologous series: same general formula; successive members differ by CH₂; show gradual variation in physical properties (e.g. boiling points); have similar chemical properties. Apply to alkane series understanding.
Describe complete combustion of hydrocarbon fuels producing carbon dioxide and water and releasing energy (exothermic). Use word/symbol equations where required.
Explain why incomplete combustion of hydrocarbons can produce carbon (soot) and carbon monoxide (insufficient oxygen).
Explain how carbon monoxide behaves as a toxic gas (binds to haemoglobin reducing oxygen transport; leads to suffocation).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Problems from CO and soot in appliances
Sub_topics.description: Describe problems caused by incomplete combustion producing carbon monoxide and soot in fuel-burning appliances (health risk, dirty deposits, reduced efficiency).
Explain how impurities in some hydrocarbon fuels lead to production of sulfur dioxide (SO₂) when burned.
Explain problems associated with acid rain caused when sulfur dioxide dissolves in rainwater (formation of acids, damage to ecosystems, buildings, and human health).
Explain why in engines oxygen and nitrogen react at high temperatures producing oxides of nitrogen (NOx) as pollutants; link to smog/acid rain/health impacts conceptually.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hydrogen vs petrol as car fuel (evaluation)
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate advantages and disadvantages of using hydrogen rather than petrol as car fuel (renewability, emissions—water only vs CO₂; storage/transport challenges, production energy, infrastructure, safety).
Recall petrol, kerosene and diesel oil are non-renewable fossil fuels obtained from crude oil; methane is non-renewable fossil fuel found in natural gas.
Explain cracking as breaking down larger saturated hydrocarbon molecules (alkanes) into smaller more useful ones, some unsaturated (alkenes). Include idea of breaking C–C bonds and producing mixture.
Explain why cracking is necessary to match supply of fractions to demand and to produce feedstock for chemicals/polymers (e.g. more petrol/alkenes).
Recall that gases produced by volcanic activity formed Earth’s early atmosphere.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Composition of early atmosphere and evidence
Sub_topics.description: Describe Earth’s early atmosphere as thought to contain little/no oxygen, large amount of carbon dioxide, water vapour, and small amounts of other gases; interpret evidence relating to this (e.g. geological, fossil).
Explain how condensation of water vapour formed oceans as Earth cooled.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: CO₂ decrease by dissolving in oceans
Sub_topics.description: Explain how atmospheric carbon dioxide decreased when CO₂ dissolved as oceans formed (and subsequent carbonate formation conceptually).
Explain how growth of primitive plants used CO₂ and released O₂ by photosynthesis, gradually increasing oxygen in atmosphere over time.
Describe chemical test for oxygen (relights a glowing splint).
Describe how gases in atmosphere including carbon dioxide, methane and water vapour absorb heat radiated from Earth and then release energy, keeping Earth warm (greenhouse effect).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evaluate evidence for human-caused climate change
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate evidence for human activity causing climate change considering: correlation between atmospheric CO₂ concentration, fossil fuel consumption and temperature change; uncertainties due to measurement location and historical accuracy. Interpret graphs/data and discuss limitations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Today's atmosphere and mitigation of greenhouse gas effects
Sub_topics.description: Describe composition of today’s atmosphere; describe potential climate effects of increased CO₂ and methane from human activities (burning fossil fuels, livestock farming); describe that effects may be mitigated and consider scale, risk and environmental implications of mitigation strategies.

Recall and use SI units for physical quantities as listed in Appendix 5 (including base units m, kg, s, A, K, mol and derived units with special names such as Hz, N, J, W, Pa, C, V, Ω, T). Apply correct units in calculations and answers.
Recall and use multiples and sub-multiples of units including giga (G), mega (M), kilo (k), centi (c), milli (m), micro (μ) and nano (n); convert between prefixed units in context.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Unit conversions including hours to seconds
Sub_topics.description: Convert between different units including hours to seconds; apply to speed, energy, power and other rate calculations.
Use significant figures and standard form where appropriate in physics calculations, including very large/small numbers, and rounding to appropriate precision consistent with data given.
Explain that a scalar quantity has magnitude (size) but no specific direction; apply to examples in motion/energy contexts.
Explain that a vector quantity has both magnitude (size) and a specific direction; represent direction where relevant.
Explain differences between vector and scalar quantities; classify quantities correctly and explain why direction matters in vectors.
Recall vector and scalar quantities including: displacement/distance, velocity/speed, acceleration, force, weight/mass, momentum, energy; use correct pairings and definitions.
Recall that velocity is speed in a stated direction; distinguish from speed as scalar.
Recall and use: average speed (m/s) = distance (m) ÷ time (s); and distance travelled (m) = average speed (m/s) × time (s). Apply to uniform motion and average speed calculations.
Analyse distance–time graphs including determination of speed from gradient; interpret straight vs curved sections and compare speeds.
Recall and use acceleration (m/s²) = change in velocity ÷ time taken; a = (v − u)/t. Apply to acceleration and deceleration problems with correct units.
Use equation v² − u² = 2 × a × x to relate initial velocity u, final velocity v, acceleration a and distance x for uniformly accelerated motion; rearrange and substitute values correctly.

Analyse velocity–time graphs to: compare accelerations qualitatively from gradients; calculate acceleration from gradient (uniform acceleration only); determine distance travelled from area under graph (uniform acceleration only). Interpret direction/sign where relevant.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Measuring speed in the lab (light gates)
Sub_topics.description: Describe laboratory methods for determining speeds of objects such as using light gates (distance/time measurement), including timing, measurement accuracy, and selection of appropriate method.
Recall typical speeds encountered in everyday life for wind and sound, and for walking, running, cycling and transport systems; use for estimation and sense-checking calculations.
Recall that acceleration g in free fall is 10 m/s² and be able to estimate magnitudes of everyday accelerations relative to this value.

Recall Newton’s first law and apply: if resultant force = 0, object at rest or moves at constant velocity; if resultant force ≠ 0, speed and/or direction changes. Apply to real examples (friction, terminal velocity conceptually).
Recall and use Newton’s second law: force (N) = mass (kg) × acceleration (m/s²), F = m a. Apply including rearrangement and unit consistency.
Define weight and recall/use W = m g where g is gravitational field strength (N/kg). Distinguish weight (N) from mass (kg) and apply to different g values.
Describe how weight is measured (newton meter/spring balance) and the need for calibration and correct units.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Weight and gravitational field strength relationship
Sub_topics.description: Describe relationship between weight and gravitational field strength (weight proportional to g for given mass); interpret changes in weight on different planets.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical: Force, mass and acceleration (trolley on ramp)
Sub_topics.description: Core Practical: Investigate relationship between force, mass and acceleration by varying masses added to trolleys on a ramp. Measure force (e.g. component of weight/added mass pulling system) and time/distance to determine acceleration; calculate acceleration; analyse how changing mass affects acceleration for a given force; consider uncertainties and controls (friction, angle).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Circular motion: changing velocity at constant speed
Sub_topics.description: Explain qualitatively that an object in circular orbit at constant speed has changing velocity because direction changes continuously (velocity is a vector).
Explain that circular motion requires a resultant force towards centre of circle called centripetal force; relate to examples (planetary orbits, cars turning).
Explain inertial mass as measure of difficulty of changing velocity and know it is defined as ratio of force to acceleration (m = F/a); relate to Newton’s second law and inertia.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Newton’s third law and momentum conservation link
Sub_topics.description: Recall and apply Newton’s third law to equilibrium and collision interactions (pairs of equal and opposite forces on different objects). Relate to conservation of momentum in collisions conceptually.
Define momentum and recall/use p = m v with units kg m/s. Apply to moving objects and compare momentum changes.
Describe examples of momentum in collisions (e.g. vehicles, sports) and relate to forces and stopping times; use qualitative reasoning and calculations where data given.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Force as rate of change of momentum
Sub_topics.description: Use Newton’s second law in momentum form: F = (mv − mu)/t (force = change in momentum ÷ time). Apply to collision/braking situations including rearrangement and units.
Explain methods of measuring human reaction times (e.g. ruler drop test) and recall typical results; interpret data distributions and factors affecting results.
Recall stopping distance = thinking distance + braking distance; use in road safety contexts.

Explain factors affecting stopping distance including mass of vehicle, speed, driver reaction time, brakes condition, road condition, and friction between tyre and road. Relate to thinking vs braking distance qualitatively and with data where given.
Describe factors affecting driver reaction time including drugs and distractions; link to increased thinking distance and accident risk.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Large decelerations and forces in crashes
Sub_topics.description: Explain dangers caused by large decelerations and estimate forces involved in typical road situations using F = Δp/Δt; relate to safety features such as crumple zones/seat belts increasing collision time to reduce force.
Recall and use ΔGPE = m g Δh to calculate change in gravitational potential energy (J) when object raised; use correct units (kg, N/kg, m) and interpret sign/meaning.
Recall and use KE = 1/2 m v² to calculate kinetic energy (J) of moving object; apply with correct units and rearrangement where needed.

Draw and interpret diagrams to represent energy transfers (e.g. Sankey diagrams, energy store and transfer pathways), showing useful and wasted/dissipated energy qualitatively/quantitatively where data given.
Explain conservation of energy: energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred between stores and pathways; total energy of a closed system remains constant.

Analyse changes in energy stores when a system changes, including: object projected upwards/up slope; moving object hitting obstacle; object accelerated by constant force; vehicle slowing down; heating water to boil in electric kettle. Identify initial/final stores and transfers (mechanical, thermal, electrical).
Explain that in a closed system energy transfers do not change total energy; energy redistributed between stores within system.
Explain that mechanical processes become wasteful when they cause temperature rise, dissipating energy as thermal energy to surroundings (e.g. friction).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Dissipation and less useful energy stores
Sub_topics.description: Explain, with examples, that energy is dissipated in all system changes so it is stored in less useful ways (typically thermal energy spread to surroundings), reducing ability to do useful work.
Explain ways of reducing unwanted energy transfer including lubrication (reducing friction) and thermal insulation (reducing conduction/convection/radiation).
Describe qualitatively effects of wall thickness and thermal conductivity on rate of cooling of a building (thicker/lower conductivity reduces energy transfer and cooling).
Recall and use efficiency = useful energy transferred by device / total energy supplied to device. Express as fraction/percentage and interpret in context.
Explain how efficiency can be increased (reducing wasted energy transfers, improving insulation/lubrication, design changes).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Energy resources on Earth (renewable vs non-renewable)
Sub_topics.description: Describe main energy sources available on Earth including fossil fuels, nuclear fuel, bio-fuel, wind, hydro-electricity, tides and the Sun; compare how renewable and non-renewable sources are used and their implications (reliability, emissions, sustainability).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Patterns and trends in energy use
Sub_topics.description: Explain patterns and trends in use of energy resources (e.g. changing mix over time, demand changes, regional differences) using data/graphs where provided.
Recall that waves transfer energy and information without transferring matter overall; apply to different wave types and examples.
Describe evidence that for water and sound waves it is the wave that travels, not the water/air itself (e.g. floating object bobbing; air particles oscillate).
Define and use frequency and wavelength for waves; understand units (Hz for frequency, m for wavelength).
Use terms amplitude, period, wave velocity (speed) and wavefront; relate period T = 1/f conceptually and to diagrams where appropriate.

Describe difference between longitudinal and transverse waves with reference to sound (longitudinal), electromagnetic waves (transverse), seismic waves, and water waves (surface waves with transverse component).
Recall and use wave speed equations: v = f λ and v = x/t (distance ÷ time). Apply to sound, water, and electromagnetic waves with unit conversions and standard form where needed.
Describe how to measure velocity of sound in air and ripples on water surfaces (e.g. time-of-flight, resonance/echo methods; ripple tank measurements) and consider accuracy.
Explain refraction at a boundary in terms of change of direction and speed when wave enters medium with different wave speed; relate bending towards/away from normal to speed change qualitatively.
Recall that different substances may absorb, transmit, refract or reflect waves in ways that vary with wavelength; apply to examples (e.g. sound absorption, EM transmission).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical: Measuring wave speed, frequency and wavelength in solid and fluid
Sub_topics.description: Core Practical: Investigate suitability of equipment to measure speed, frequency and wavelength of a wave in a solid and a fluid. Expected contexts: ripple tank for waves in liquid; metal rod for waves in solid with method to measure frequency. Use v = f λ and evaluate measurement methods/apparatus suitability and uncertainty.

Topics.Topic_name: Topic 5 – Light and the electromagnetic spectrum

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electromagnetic waves are transverse and same speed in vacuum
Sub_topics.description: Recall all electromagnetic (EM) waves are transverse and travel at same speed in a vacuum (c ≈ 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s).
