Explain, with examples, that all EM waves transfer energy from source to observer (heating, excitation, ionisation depending on frequency).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical: Refraction in glass blocks (light interaction with matter)
Sub_topics.description: Core Practical: Investigate refraction in rectangular glass blocks. Use light source with grating to produce a beam; measure incident and refracted rays/angles; describe interaction with glass and how changing medium affects direction (towards/away from normal). Emphasise accurate ray tracing, normal line, and safety with light sources.
Recall main groupings of continuous EM spectrum in order: radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible (colours), ultraviolet, x-rays, gamma rays.

Describe EM spectrum as continuous from radio to gamma; radiations grouped in order of decreasing wavelength and increasing frequency; link λ and f inversely using v = f λ (with v constant in vacuum).
Recall eyes detect only limited range of frequencies (visible light) within EM spectrum; relate to colours and wavelength range qualitatively.
Recall different substances may absorb, transmit, refract or reflect EM waves in ways that vary with wavelength; apply to material choice (e.g. glass vs infrared, metal reflectors).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Different velocities of EM waves in substances
Sub_topics.description: Explain effects of differences in velocities of EM waves in different substances (refraction; speed changes with refractive index; wavelength changes while frequency stays constant).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: EM wave danger increases with frequency
Sub_topics.description: Recall potential danger associated with an EM wave increases with increasing frequency (greater energy per photon; ionising at high frequencies).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Harmful effects of EM radiation exposure
Sub_topics.description: Describe harmful effects of excessive exposure: microwaves—internal heating of body cells; infrared—skin burns; ultraviolet—damage to surface cells/eyes leading to skin cancer and eye conditions; x-rays and gamma rays—mutation or damage to body cells (ionisation).

Describe uses of EM radiation: radio—broadcasting/communications/satellites; microwaves—cooking/communications/satellites; infrared—cooking/thermal imaging/short range communications/optical fibres/TV remotes/security; visible—vision/photography/illumination; ultraviolet—security marking/fluorescent lamps/detecting forged notes/disinfecting water; x-rays—internal structure/airport scanners/medical imaging; gamma—sterilising food/equipment, detection and treatment of cancer.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Radio waves and oscillations in circuits
Sub_topics.description: Recall radio waves can be produced by, or induce, oscillations in electrical circuits; link to transmitting/receiving aerials conceptually.

Recall that changes in atoms and nuclei can generate radiations over wide frequency range and can be caused by absorption of a range of radiations (excitation/ionisation/nuclear transitions conceptually).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Atomic model: nucleus and electrons; scale
Sub_topics.description: Describe an atom as positively charged nucleus (protons and neutrons) surrounded by negatively charged electrons; nuclear radius much smaller than atom; almost all mass in nucleus; relate to scale models and structure.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Typical size of atoms and small molecules
Sub_topics.description: Recall typical size (order of magnitude) of atoms and small molecules and apply to comparisons/estimations.
Describe structure of nuclei of isotopes using atomic (proton) number and mass (nucleon) number and symbols in format e.g. ¹³₆C; interpret symbols to determine numbers of protons/neutrons.

Recall nucleus of each element has characteristic positive charge (proton number) but isotopes differ in mass because they have different numbers of neutrons; relate to nuclear stability concepts qualitatively.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Relative masses and charges incl positrons
Sub_topics.description: Recall relative masses and relative electric charges of protons, neutrons, electrons and positrons (positron has same mass as electron and +1 charge).
Recall that in an atom number of protons equals number of electrons, so atom is neutral overall.
Recall electrons orbit nucleus at different set distances (shells/energy levels) from nucleus; relate to electron configuration conceptually.
Explain electrons change orbit/energy level when EM radiation is absorbed or emitted; relate to photon energy differences qualitatively.
Explain how atoms form positive ions by losing outer electrons; relate to electron shells and ion charge.
Recall alpha, β− (beta minus), β+ (positron), gamma rays and neutron radiation are emitted from unstable nuclei in a random process; understand unpredictability of individual decays.
Recall alpha, β−, β+ and gamma rays are ionising radiations; relate ionisation to ability to remove electrons from atoms/molecules.
Explain what is meant by background radiation (radiation always present in environment from natural and man-made sources).
Describe origins of background radiation from Earth and space (radon and rocks, cosmic rays, medical, nuclear).
Describe methods for measuring/detecting radioactivity limited to photographic film and Geiger–Müller tube; include count rate and background subtraction conceptually.
Recall alpha particle is helium nucleus, beta particle is electron emitted from nucleus, gamma ray is electromagnetic radiation; include penetration/ionisation implications.
Compare alpha, beta and gamma radiations in terms of penetrating power and ionising ability (alpha highly ionising low penetration; gamma least ionising high penetration).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Atomic model development (plum pudding to Bohr)
Sub_topics.description: Describe how atomic model changed over time including plum pudding model and Rutherford alpha scattering leading to Bohr model; link evidence from scattering to nucleus concept.
Describe β− decay: a neutron becomes a proton plus an electron (and electron emitted from nucleus). Understand resulting change in atomic number (+1) and mass number (no change).
Describe β+ decay: a proton becomes a neutron plus a positron (positron emitted). Understand resulting change in atomic number (−1) and mass number (no change).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Effect of decay on proton and nucleon numbers
Sub_topics.description: Explain effects on atomic (proton) number and mass (nucleon) number of radioactive decays (α, β, γ and neutron emission). Include: alpha reduces proton number by 2 and mass number by 4; beta changes proton number by ±1; gamma no change; neutron emission reduces mass number by 1 with no proton change.
Recall nuclei that have undergone radioactive decay often rearrange and lose energy as gamma radiation; relate to excited nucleus returning to lower energy state.
Use given data to balance nuclear equations in terms of mass (nucleon) number and charge (proton) number, conserving both across reaction/decay equations.
Describe how activity of a radioactive source decreases over time as unstable nuclei decay; interpret activity-time graphs qualitatively.
Recall unit of activity is the Becquerel (Bq), equal to one decay per second.
Explain half-life as time taken for half the undecayed nuclei to decay or for activity of a source to fall to half its initial value.
Explain that timing of decay of a particular nucleus cannot be predicted but half-life allows prediction for large numbers of nuclei; relate to randomness and probability.
Use concept of half-life to carry out simple calculations on decay of radioactive isotope, including graphical representations (counting half-lives, using ratios/fractions, reading from graphs).
Describe dangers of ionising radiation in terms of tissue damage and possible mutations; relate hazard to ionising power, penetration, dose and exposure time; link to safety precautions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Radiation safety precautions and dose limiting
Sub_topics.description: Explain precautions to ensure safety of people exposed to radiation including limiting dose for patients and risks to medical personnel (time, distance, shielding; monitoring).

Describe differences between contamination and irradiation effects and compare hazards associated with each (contamination involves radioactive material on/in body leading to internal exposure; irradiation is exposure to radiation without material transfer).
Describe changes involved in way energy is stored when systems change; identify relevant stores (kinetic, gravitational, elastic, thermal, chemical, etc.) and transfers.
Draw and interpret diagrams representing energy transfers, showing pathways such as work done by forces, electrical transfer, and heating; relate to useful vs dissipated energy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Closed systems and total energy constant
Sub_topics.description: Explain that in closed system with energy transfers there is no net change to total energy; apply conservation of energy to system diagrams.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ways energy of a system can be changed
Sub_topics.description: Identify different ways energy of a system can be changed: through work done by forces, in electrical equipment, and in heating processes; relate to examples.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Work done by force and energy transfer
Sub_topics.description: Describe how to measure work done by a force; understand that energy transferred (J) equals work done (J) and interpret as transfer by mechanical work.
Recall and use work done (J) = force (N) × distance moved in direction of force (m): E = F d. Apply to horizontal/vertical movement in direction of force and include unit consistency.
Describe and calculate energy changes involved when system changed by work done by forces (e.g. lifting, pushing with friction) using E=Fd and linking to store changes.
Recall and use ΔGPE = m g Δh for changes in gravitational potential energy in forces-doing-work contexts, relating to work done against weight.
Recall and use KE = 1/2 m v² in work/energy contexts, including acceleration by forces and braking.
Explain, using examples, how energy is dissipated in all system changes and stored in less useful ways (mainly thermal) due to friction, electrical resistance, etc.
Explain mechanical processes become wasteful when they cause temperature rise dissipating energy to surroundings; relate to friction/drag.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Power as rate of energy transfer
Sub_topics.description: Define power as rate of energy transfer (or work done per second) and use examples to explain definition (higher power transfers energy faster).
Recall and use power (W) = work done or energy transferred (J) ÷ time taken (s): P = E/t. Apply with unit conversions and rearrangement.
Recall that one watt equals one joule per second (1 W = 1 J/s).
Recall and use efficiency = useful energy transferred by device / total energy supplied to device; apply to mechanical/electrical devices in work/power contexts.

Describe how objects interact: (a) at a distance without contact via gravitational, electrostatic and magnetic fields; (b) by contact including normal contact force and friction; (c) producing pairs of forces representable as vectors (Newton’s third law pairs).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Vector vs scalar in force contexts
Sub_topics.description: Explain difference between vector and scalar quantities using examples from forces and motion (e.g. force vs energy; velocity vs speed).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Vector diagrams: resolution, resultant and equilibrium
Sub_topics.description: Use vector diagrams to illustrate resolution of forces, net/resultant force, and equilibrium situations using scale drawings only. Determine resultant qualitatively/quantitatively from scaled vectors.
Draw and use free-body force diagrams showing forces acting on object (weight, normal, friction, tension, thrust, drag) with correct directions and labels; use to reason about resultants.

Explain examples of forces on isolated object/system where multiple forces lead to resultant force; special case balanced forces where resultant is zero; link to Newton’s first law outcomes (rest/constant velocity).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reducing unwanted energy transfer by lubrication
Sub_topics.description: Explain lubrication reduces friction between surfaces, reducing unwanted energy transfer to thermal energy and improving efficiency and wear reduction.
Describe atom structure limited to position, mass and charge of protons, neutrons and electrons; relate to electrical phenomena (electrons as charge carriers in metals).

Draw and use electric circuit diagrams with correct conventions for positive/negative terminals and symbols for: cells/batteries, switches, voltmeters, ammeters, resistors, variable resistors, lamps, motors, diodes, thermistors, LDRs and LEDs.
Describe differences between series and parallel circuits (single loop vs branches; current/voltage distribution; effect of component failure).
Recall voltmeter is connected in parallel with a component to measure potential difference (voltage) across it; use correctly in circuit set-ups.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Potential difference as energy per charge
Sub_topics.description: Explain potential difference (voltage) as energy transferred per unit charge; 1 volt = 1 joule per coulomb (1 V = 1 J/C).
Recall and use E = Q V where energy transferred (J) = charge moved (C) × potential difference (V). Apply to electrical devices and rearrange as needed.
Recall ammeter is connected in series with component to measure current through it (A).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Current as rate of flow of charge; electrons in metals
Sub_topics.description: Explain electric current as rate of flow of charge; in metals current is flow of electrons; relate direction of conventional current vs electron flow conceptually.
Recall and use Q = I t where charge (C) = current (A) × time (s). Apply to circuit problems and rearrange with unit conversions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Current in closed circuit with p.d. source
Sub_topics.description: Describe that when a closed circuit includes a source of potential difference, there will be a current in the circuit; relate to complete path and push on charges.
Recall current is conserved at a junction in a circuit (sum of currents into junction = sum out); apply to parallel branch calculations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Resistance changes affect current; variable resistor
Sub_topics.description: Explain how changing resistance changes current in a circuit (I = V/R) and how to achieve using variable resistor; relate to dimmer controls and control circuits.
Recall and use V = I R where potential difference (V) = current (A) × resistance (Ω). Apply to resistors, lamps, and circuit calculations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Equivalent resistance in series and parallel (qualitative)
Sub_topics.description: Explain why net resistance increases when resistors in series; decreases when resistors in parallel; relate to current paths and total opposition to charge flow.
Calculate currents, potential differences and resistances in series circuits (same current; voltages add; resistances add). Use V=IR and equivalent resistance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Design and construction of series circuits for testing
Sub_topics.description: Explain design and construction of series circuits for testing and measuring (placing meters correctly, controlling variables, safe set-up).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical: I–V characteristics and series/parallel circuits
Sub_topics.description: Core Practical: Construct electrical circuits to (a) investigate relationship between potential difference, current and resistance for a resistor and a filament lamp by recording I at different V and plotting I–V graphs; (b) test series and parallel circuits using resistors and filament lamps with ammeters/voltmeters to compare readings. Include analysis using V = I R and discussion of linear vs non-linear behaviour and measurement uncertainty.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: I–V behaviour of components (lamp, diode, resistor)
Sub_topics.description: Explain how current varies with potential difference for filament lamps, diodes and fixed resistors and how this relates to resistance (lamp: resistance increases with temperature; diode: current flows mainly one direction after threshold; resistor: linear/ohmic).
Describe how resistance of a light-dependent resistor (LDR) varies with light intensity (higher light → lower resistance) and apply to sensor circuits.
Describe how resistance of a negative temperature coefficient (NTC) thermistor varies with temperature (higher temperature → lower resistance) and apply to control/sensing contexts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Using circuits to explore resistance changes (components)
Sub_topics.description: Explain how circuit design and use can explore variation of resistance in filament lamps, diodes, thermistors and LDRs (measurement of I–V, controlled variables, use of potential divider conceptually).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Heating effect of current in resistors
Sub_topics.description: Recall that when electric current flows in a resistor, energy transfer heats the resistor (electrical energy to thermal energy).
Explain that electrical energy is dissipated as thermal energy in surroundings when current does work against resistance; relate to efficiency and heat loss in wires.
Explain heating effect as result of collisions between electrons and ions in lattice, transferring energy to vibrations (increased thermal energy).
Explain ways to reduce unwanted energy transfer through low resistance wires (thicker wires, better conductors, shorter lengths) to reduce heating losses.
Describe advantages and disadvantages of heating effect of an electric current (useful in heaters/kettles; undesirable in transmission lines/electronics).
Use equation E = I V t to calculate energy transferred (J) = current (A) × potential difference (V) × time (s). Apply to appliances and include unit conversions.
Describe power as energy transferred per second and recall measured in watt; relate to appliance ratings.
Recall and use P = E/t for electrical power calculations; combine with E=IVt where needed.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Power related to V and I
Sub_topics.description: Explain how power transfer in a circuit device relates to potential difference across it and current through it (P = IV).
Recall and use P = I V and P = I² R; apply to resistive components and energy loss calculations, rearranging as needed.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Energy transfers in domestic devices (batteries and mains)
Sub_topics.description: Describe how in domestic devices energy transfers from batteries and a.c. mains to motors and heating devices; link electrical energy to kinetic/thermal stores.
Explain difference between direct and alternating voltage (direction/polarity constant vs periodic reversal).
Describe d.c. as movement of charge in one direction only; recall cells and batteries supply d.c.
Describe that in a.c. movement of charge changes direction periodically.
Recall UK domestic supply is a.c. at frequency 50 Hz and voltage about 230 V.
Explain difference in function between live and neutral mains input wires (live alternates at high potential relative to earth; neutral near 0 V; completes circuit).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Earth wire, fuses and circuit breakers (safety)
Sub_topics.description: Explain function of earth wire and of fuses/circuit breakers in ensuring safety (providing low resistance path for fault current; disconnecting supply when current too high).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Fuses and switches in live wire
Sub_topics.description: Explain why switches and fuses should be connected in live wire of domestic circuit to isolate appliance from live potential when off/faulted.
Recall potential differences between live, neutral and earth mains wires (live ~230 V relative to neutral/earth; neutral ~0 V; earth ~0 V).
Explain dangers of any connection between live wire and earth (large fault current, electric shock risk, overheating/fire) and protective action of fuse/MCB.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Appliance power ratings and energy changes
Sub_topics.description: Describe, with examples, relationship between power ratings of domestic appliances and changes in stored energy when in use (energy = power × time; higher power transfers energy faster).

Topics.Topic_name: Topic 12 – Magnetism and the motor effect

Sub_topics.description: Recall unlike magnetic poles attract and like magnetic poles repel; apply to bar magnets and field interactions.
Describe uses of permanent and temporary magnetic materials including cobalt, steel, iron and nickel; link to retention of magnetism and application contexts (electromagnets, cores).
Explain difference between permanent magnets and induced magnets (magnetised only in presence of field, usually in soft iron).
Describe shape and direction of magnetic field around bar magnets and uniform fields; relate field strength to concentration (density) of field lines and direction from N to S outside magnet.
Describe use of plotting compasses to show shape and direction of magnetic field of a magnet and Earth’s magnetic field; interpret compass alignment with field lines.
Explain how behaviour of magnetic compass provides evidence Earth’s core must be magnetic; relate to alignment with Earth's field.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Magnetic field around a current-carrying conductor
Sub_topics.description: Describe how to show current creates magnetic effect and relate shape/direction of magnetic field around long straight conductor to direction of current (right-hand grip rule conceptually).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Field strength vs current and distance
Sub_topics.description: Recall that strength of magnetic field around long straight conductor depends on size of current and distance from conductor (stronger with larger current; weaker further away).
Explain that inside a solenoid fields from individual coils add to form strong, almost uniform field along centre; outside they largely cancel giving weaker external field; relate to electromagnets.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Force on current-carrying conductor near magnet
Sub_topics.description: Recall that a current-carrying conductor near a magnet experiences a force and equal/opposite force acts on magnet; link to motor effect and Newton’s third law.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Magnetic forces due to field interactions
Sub_topics.description: Explain magnetic forces are due to interactions between magnetic fields (superposition leading to attraction/repulsion/force).
Recall and use Fleming’s left-hand rule to represent relative directions of force, current and magnetic field when mutually perpendicular; apply to motor effect problems.

Use equation F = B I l for force on conductor at right angles to magnetic field: force (N) = magnetic flux density B (T or N/A m) × current I (A) × length l (m). Substitute and rearrange with correct units.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Factors affecting induced p.d. and opposition (Lenz’s law)
Sub_topics.description: Recall factors affecting size and direction of induced potential difference and describe how induced magnetic field opposes original change (qualitative Lenz’s law). Consider speed of change, field strength, and relative motion conceptually.
Explain how an alternating current in one circuit can induce a current in another in a transformer (changing magnetic field in primary induces p.d. in secondary).
Recall that a transformer can change size of an alternating voltage (step-up or step-down).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: National grid: high voltage for efficiency
Sub_topics.description: Explain why electrical energy is transferred at high voltages in national grid then lowered for domestic use to improve efficiency by reducing heat loss in transmission lines (lower current for same power reduces I²R losses).

Explain where and why step-up and step-down transformers are used in transmission of electricity in national grid (step-up at power station for transmission; step-down near consumers for safety and appliance requirements).
Use transformer power equation for 100% efficiency: Vp Ip = Vs Is. Apply to calculate unknown voltage/current in primary/secondary and interpret as power conservation (neglecting losses).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Kinetic theory and states of matter
Sub_topics.description: Use simple kinetic theory model to explain solids, liquids and gases in terms of particle arrangement and motion; relate temperature to average kinetic energy qualitatively.
Recall and use density equation: ρ (kg/m³) = mass m (kg) ÷ volume V (m³). Convert units (e.g. g/cm³ to kg/m³) where needed and apply to objects/fluids.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical: Densities of solids and liquids
Sub_topics.description: Core Practical: Investigate densities of solids and liquids. Determine solid density by measuring mass and volume (volume by water displacement). Determine liquid density by measuring mass of known volume. Use ρ = m/V; consider accuracy, meniscus reading, and repeats.
Explain differences in density between states of matter using particle arrangements (gases low density due to spacing; solids usually highest due to close packing; liquids intermediate).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mass conservation in changes of state
Sub_topics.description: Describe that mass is conserved when substances change state (melt, freeze, evaporate, boil, condense, sublimate) and these physical changes differ from chemical changes because original properties are recovered if change reversed.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Heating, temperature and changes of state
Sub_topics.description: Explain heating changes energy stored within system and raises temperature or produces change of state; relate to energy for increasing kinetic energy vs breaking intermolecular bonds at phase changes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Specific heat capacity vs specific latent heat
Sub_topics.description: Define specific heat capacity and specific latent heat and explain difference: c relates energy to temperature change without state change; L relates energy to change of state at constant temperature.
Use equation ΔQ = m c Δθ where change in thermal energy (J) = mass (kg) × specific heat capacity (J/kg °C) × temperature change (°C). Apply to heating/cooling problems and rearrange.
Use equation Q = m L where thermal energy for change of state (J) = mass (kg) × specific latent heat (J/kg). Apply to melting/boiling problems and rearrange.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Thermal insulation to reduce energy transfer
Sub_topics.description: Explain ways of reducing unwanted energy transfer through thermal insulation (materials with low thermal conductivity; reducing convection with trapped air; reflective surfaces reduce radiation).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical: Properties of water (SHC and melting ice temperature-time graph)
Sub_topics.description: Core Practical: Investigate properties of water by (1) determining specific heat capacity of water using heat supply connected to joulemeter while monitoring temperature; calculate c from ΔQ=mcΔθ; (2) obtaining temperature–time graph for melting ice: record temperature of crushed ice, melt using water bath (beaker of water heated with Bunsen burner), monitor temperature as ice melts. Include method, graphing, and uncertainties/controls.
Explain pressure of a gas in terms of particle motion and collisions with container walls producing force per unit area; relate pressure changes to collision frequency/momentum change conceptually.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Temperature effect on gas particle speed and pressure (qualitative)
Sub_topics.description: Explain qualitatively effect of changing gas temperature on particle velocity and hence pressure for fixed mass of gas at constant volume (higher temperature → faster particles → more frequent/forceful collisions → higher pressure).
Describe absolute zero (−273 °C) in terms of lack of movement of particles (minimum internal energy, extrapolated).
Convert between kelvin and Celsius temperature scales: T(K) = θ(°C) + 273. Apply to problems involving absolute temperature.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Elastic objects require more than one force
Sub_topics.description: Explain, using springs and other elastic objects, that stretching, bending or compressing requires more than one force (internal restoring forces and external applied forces; tension/compression).
Describe difference between elastic distortion (returns to original shape when forces removed) and inelastic distortion (permanent deformation).
Recall and use equation for linear elastic distortion: F = k x, including calculating spring constant k (N/m). Understand applies up to limit of proportionality; use correct units and graphs.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Work done stretching spring (elastic potential energy)
Sub_topics.description: Use equation for work done/energy transferred stretching a spring: E = 0.5 k x². Apply to calculate energy stored in spring and relate to area under force-extension graph for linear region.
Describe difference between linear and non-linear relationships between force and extension; interpret force–extension graphs including limit of proportionality and yielding/breaking points.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical: Spring extension and work done
Sub_topics.description: Core Practical: Investigate extension and work done when applying forces to a spring. Measure natural length then length with varying masses/forces; calculate extension x and force F (using W=mg if masses hung); plot force–extension graph, identify linear region, determine k from gradient; calculate work done/energy using E = 0.5 k x² and/or area under graph. Consider repeats, zero error and safety with masses.
